Hockey East Tournament Champions
Beanpot Champions |NCAATourney = [[2010 NCAA Division I Men's Ice Hockey Tournament|NCAA Championship Game]] |NCAATourneyResult = W 5-0 vs. [[Wisconsin Badgers men's ice hockey|Wisconsin]]
[[2010 Hockey East Men's Ice Hockey Tournament|Hockey East Championship]], W 7-6 (OT) vs. [[Maine Black Bears men's ice hockey|Maine]]
[[Beanpot (ice hockey)|Beanpot Championship]], W 4-3 vs. [[Boston University Terriers men's ice hockey|Boston University]] |prevseason = [[2008â09 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey season|2008-09]] |nextseason = [[2010â11 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey season|2010-11]] |headerstyle = background:#8B0000; color:#F0E68C; |labelstyle = background:#eeeeee; }} The '''2009-2010 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey team''' represented [[Boston College]] in the 2009-2010 college hockey season. The team was coached by [[Jerry York]], '67, his sixteenth season behind the bench at Boston College. The Eagles played their home games at [[Conte Forum|Kelley Rink]] on the campus of Boston College, and competed in [[Hockey East]]. Boston College defeated [[Wisconsin Badgers men's ice hockey|Wisconsin]] 5-0 in the [[2010 NCAA Division I Men's Ice Hockey Tournament|2010 Frozen Four]] Championship Game, earning the school's fourth national championship and second title in three years. The Eagles defeated [[Alaska Nanooks men's ice hockey|Alaska]] and [[Yale Bulldogs men's ice hockey|Yale]] in the Northeast Regional in [[Worcester, MA|Worcester]], earning them a berth in the Frozen Four to be played at [[Ford Field]] in [[Detroit]]. BC defeated Miami (OH) 7-1 in the national semifinal, the fourth time in five years that the Eagles ended the RedHawks' season in the NCAA Tournament, before meeting Wisconsin in the final. The game was played before a record crowd of 37,592, the largest to attend an indoor hockey game.http://www.uscho.com/recaps/20092010/m/04/10/bc-uw.php The 5-0 win in the National Championship Game was also Jerry York's 850th career victory. After finishing second behind [[New Hampshire Wildcats|New Hampshire]] in the 2009-2010 Hockey East Regular Season, the Eagles won the [[2010 Hockey East Men's Ice Hockey Tournament|2010 Hockey East Tournament]], defeating [[Maine Black Bears men's ice hockey|Maine]] 7-6 in overtime in the championship game, gaining their record ninth league title. BC also won the 2010 [[Beanpot (ice hockey)|Beanpot Tournament]], defeating rivals [[Boston University Terriers men's ice hockey|Boston University]] 4-3 in the final game to earn their fifteenth championship. On January 8, 2010, Boston College and Boston University faced off at [[Fenway Park]] in the first men's college hockey game played at the home of the [[Boston Red Sox]]. BU edged BC 3-2 before a sellout crowd of 38,472.http://hockeyeastonline.com/men/recaps10.php?mbc_bu_1.j08 ==Recruiting== Boston College added nine freshmen for the 2009-2010 season, including four defensemen, four forwards, and one goalie. {|class="wikitable" width="70%" |- align="center" style="background:#8B0000;color:#F0E68C;" | '''Player''' || '''Position''' || '''Nationality''' || '''Notes''' |- align="center" bgcolor="" |Brian Dumoulin|| Defense || {{USA}} || [[Biddeford, ME]]; Selected 51st overall by [[Carolina Hurricanes|CAR]] in [[2009 NHL Entry Draft|2009 draft]]. |- align="center" bgcolor="" |[[Philip Samuelsson]]|| Defense || {{USA}} || [[Scottsdale, AZ]]; Selected 61st overall by [[Pittsburgh Penguins|PIT]] in [[2009 NHL Entry Draft|2009 draft]]. |- align="center" bgcolor="" | Patrick Wey || Defense|| {{USA}} || [[Pittsburgh, PA]]; Selected 115th overall by [[Washington Capitals|WAS]] in [[2009 NHL Entry Draft|2009 draft]]. |- align="center" bgcolor="" | Pat Mullane || Forward || {{USA}} || [[Wallingford, CT]]; Played along side teammate [[Cam Atkinson]] at [[Avon Old Farms]]. |- align="center" bgcolor="" | Brooks Dyroff || Forward || {{USA}} || [[Boulder, CO]]; Also an accomplished young filmmaker. |- align="center" bgcolor="" | [[Chris Kreider]] || Forward || {{USA}} || [[Boxford, MA]]; Selected 19th overall by [[New York Rangers|NYR]] in [[2009 NHL Entry Draft|2009 draft]]. |- align="center" bgcolor="" | Steven Whitney || Forward || {{USA}} || [[Reading, MA]]; Younger brother of teammate Joe Whitney. |- align="center" bgcolor="" | Patch Alber || Defense || {{USA}} || [[Clifton Park, NY]]; Earned [[EJHL]] All-Star recognition with [[Boston Jr. Bruins|Boston]] in 2008-09. |- align="center" bgcolor="" | Parker Milner || Goalie|| {{USA}} || [[Pittsburgh, PA]];
